body:
So, specifically, 5.2.2 says that it gets it from the 'base URI'. Section 5.1 describes how the base is resolved. What browsers do is 5.1.1: it gets it from being embedded. In some contexts, it'd go to 5.1.4, which basically says "lol whatevs".

> A sender of a representation containing relative references is
>   responsible for ensuring that a base URI for those references can be
>   established.  Aside from fragment-only references, relative
>   references can only be used reliably in situations where the base URI
>   is well defined.

So, maybe this answers my question: because it can be 'it depends,' it may not be a good default.
